item.title: Natural variation in mineral content of a food is typically 3 to 1
item.description:
Mineral nutrient composition of vegetables, fruits and grains: The context of reports of apparent historical declines

Journal of Food Composition and Analysis http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jfca.2016.11.012

Robin J. Marles robin.marles@hc-sc.gc.ca

Senior Scientific Advisor, Nutrition Premarket Assessment Division, Bureau of Nutritional Sciences, Food Directorate, Health Canada, 251 Sir Frederick Banting Driveway (Mail Stop 2203E), Ottawa, Ontario K1A 0K9, Canada

  • Nicely describes why most of the alarmest reports of declines should not be believed.

  • Documents the huge variation in mineral content due to differences in climate, species, cultivars, etc. - see table below

item.title: Upsurge in Metabolic diseases may be due to low vitamin D
item.description:
Vitamin D Deficiency - A Missing Link in The Upsurge of Metabolic Diseases??

INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH Volume : 5 | Issue : 5 | May 2016

M.Sc, PhD Biochemistry; Associate Professor, Department of Biochemistry, Vivekananda Institute of Medical Sciences, Rama Krishna Mission Seva Pratishhan, Kolkata, India * Corresponding Author

Download the PDF from VitaminDWiki

Co-occurances of Metabolic Syndrome Diseases (Table 1)

Venn diagram: Overlap of Metabolic Syndromes if have low vitamin D (Figure 5)

  • Metabolic Syndrome indicators inversely proportional to vitamin D below 46 ng – Nov 2018

item.title: Is a health problem associated with Low vitamin D, Low Magnesium, or too much Calcium
item.description:
Essential Nutrient Interactions: Does Low or Suboptimal Magnesium Status Interact with Vitamin D and/or Calcium Status?

Adv Nutr. 2016 Jan 15;7(1):25-43. doi: 10.3945/an.115.008631. Print 2016 Jan.

Rosanoff A1, Dai Q2, Shapses SA3.

1 Center for Magnesium Education and Research, Pahoa, HI; arosanoff@gmail.com.

2 Vanderbilt Epidemiology Center, Department of Medicine, School of Medicine, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN

3 Rutgers University, New Brunswick, NJ.

Optimum Calcium somewhere 1.7 - 2.5 X Magnesium China says 2.0 X

item.title: Magnesium in Prevention and Therapy – (28 pages)
item.description:
Nutrients ISSN 2072-6643

Uwe Grober uwegroeber@gmx.net , Joachim Schmidt1 and Klaus Kisters 1,2

Academy of Micronutrient Medicine, Essen 45130, Germany;

E-Mails: Prof.schmidt.dd@t-online.de (J.S.); kisters@annahospital.de (K.K.)

Department of Internal Medicine I, St. Anna-Hospital, Herne 44649, Germany

Received: 18 June 2015 /Accepted: 11 September 2015 /Published: 23 September 2015

Abstract:

Magnesium is the fourth most abundant mineral in the body. It has been recognized as a cofactor for more than 300 enzymatic reactions, where it is crucial for adenosine triphosphate (ATP) metabolism. Magnesium is required for DNA and RNA synthesis, reproduction, and protein synthesis. Moreover, magnesium is essential for the regulation of muscular contraction, blood pressure, insulin metabolism, cardiac excitability, vasomotor tone, nerve transmission and neuromuscular conduction. Imbalances in magnesium status—primarily hypomagnesemia as it is seen more common than hypermagnesemia—might result in unwanted neuromuscular, cardiac or nervous disorders. Based on magnesium’s many functions within the human body, it plays an important role in prevention and treatment of many diseases. Low levels of magnesium have been associated with a number of chronic diseases, such as Alzheimer’s disease, insulin resistance and type-2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, cardiovascular disease (e.g., stroke), migraine headaches, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

item.title: Vitamin D, Calcium and protein very important to bone health

Synthesis Medical NZ Ltd, Auckland, New Zealand

University of Notre Dame Australia, Sydney, Australia

NIHR Musculoskeletal Biomedical Research Unit, Nuffield Dept of Orthopaedics, Rheumatology and Musculoskeletal Sciences, U. of Oxford, Oxford, UK

MRC Lifecourse Epidemiology Unit, University of Southampton, Southampton General Hospital, Southampton, UK

Jean Mayer USDA Human Nutrition Research Center on Aging, Tufts University, Boston, MA, USA

item.title: Vitamin D Receptor
item.description:
1. It appears that 1/3 of everyone with a vitamin D-related disease has a poor VDR

  2. A poor VDR cannot be detected by any standard Vitamin D test (nor Calcitriol nor Calcidiol)

  3. A poor Parathyroid VDR can be detected when high Calcitriol levels fail to decrease PTH levels

Decreasing PTH shows Vitamin D is getting to Parathyroid - but says nothing about VDRs elsewhere

  1. Many cancers and viruses have learned to protect themselves by deactivating the local VDR

item.title: ICU death 2X more likely if low vitamin D (sensitivity and selectivity chart)

Vitamin D deficiency is independently associated with mortality among critically ill patients

Rafael Barberena MoraesI*, Gilberto FriedmanI, Iuri Christmann WawrzeniakI, Leonardo S. MarquesI, Fabiano Márcio NagelI, Thiago Costa LisboaI, Mauro Antonio CzepielewskiII

IUniversidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul, Department of Internal Medicine, Division of Critical Care Medicine, Porto Alegre/RS, Brazil

IIUniversidade Federal do Rio Grande do Sul, Hospital de Clínicas de Porto Alegre, Department of Internal Medicine, Division of Endocrinology, Porto Alegre/RS, Brazil.

item.title: Hypertension reduced by Omega-3, especially if previously untreated – meta-analysis
item.description:
• Long-chain omega-3 fatty acids eicosapentaenoic acid and docosahexaenoic acid and blood pressure: a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
      • Omega-3 and Cardiovascular – review Sept 2013

Omega-3 is one of a constellation of supplements, all of which reduce hypertension

Omega-3, Magneisum, Vitamin D

Each of them improve health and they appear to be synegistic (help each other)

I personally take all three - Henry Lahore - admin VitaminDWiki

See also VitaminDWiki

item.title: Metabolic Syndrome risk decreases 12 percent with 150 mg of Magnesium – meta-analysis
item.description:
• Meta-analysis Dec 2014
      • MetS still after 382 mg of Mg = 48%, placebo 77.5% - May 2018
      • See also VitaminDWiki

Meta-analysis Dec 2014

Dietary magnesium intake and metabolic syndrome in the adult population: dose-response meta-analysis and meta-regression.

Nutrients. 2014 Dec 22;6(12):6005-19. doi: 10.3390/nu6126005.

Increasing evidence has suggested an association between dietary magnesium intake and metabolic syndrome. However, previous research examining dietary magnesium intake and metabolic syndrome has produced mixed results.

Our objective was to determine the relationship between dietary magnesium intake and metabolic syndrome in the adult population using a dose-response meta-analysis.

item.title: UV (perhaps Nitric Oxide) better than vitamin D at preventing obesity in rats on a high-fat diet
item.description:
• Ultraviolet radiation suppresses obesity and symptoms of metabolic syndrome independently of vitamin D in mice fed a high-fat diet.
      • See also VitaminDWiki

Ultraviolet radiation suppresses obesity and symptoms of metabolic syndrome independently of vitamin D in mice fed a high-fat diet.

Diabetes. 2014 Nov;63(11):3759-69. doi: 10.2337/db13-1675.

Geldenhuys S 1, Hart PH 1, Endersby R 1, Jacoby P 1, Feelisch M 2, Weller RB 3, Matthews V 4, Gorman S 5.

1 Telethon Kids Institute, The University of Western Australia, Perth, Western Australia, Australia.

item.title: Kidney stone production REDUCED in rats when Vitamin D and Calcium was added
item.description:
Effect of vitamin D3 overdose and calcium supplementation in experimental nephrolithiasis model

Introduction: There is little information in the literature relating supplementary oral usage of vitamin D and calcium to the development of kidney stones.

Objective: To evaluate the effect of high dose, 200 IU of vitamin D3 (V) with calcium supplementation (Ca).

Methods: Experimental model consists of insertion of pellets into the bladder of rats. V was administered for 30 days with or without Ca.

item.title: Fructose (High Fructose Corn Syrup) consumes 2X more Magnesium than sugar
item.description:
High Fructose Corn Syrup and the Obesity Epidemic Dr. Carolyn Dean

  • it takes 28 molecules of magnesium to metabolize one molecule of sucrose (table sugar).

  • it takes 56 molecules of magnesium to metabolize one molecule of fructose.

See also VitaminDWiki

  • Bad effects of fructose diet offset by Vitamin D supplementation (mice) - June 2019

item.title: Vitamin D intervention – 1204 clinical trials
item.description:
Data is US Clinical Trials

There have been more US intervention trials for vitamin D than for vitamins A, C, E, and K combined

D = 1204, vs 1023 = Total A+C+E+K (A =225 + C =340 + E =328 + K =130)

Other statistics for US Vitamin D Intervention trials

  • 802 trials for those 65+

  • 252 trials for children (age 0-17)

  • 1071 trials updated information since Jan 2010

  • 744 trials registered since Jan 2010

item.title: Prediabetics not helped by weekly vitamin D (perhaps D2) – RCT
item.description:
High-dose vitamin D supplementation in people with prediabetes and hypovitaminosis D.

Diabetes Care. 2013 Feb;36(2):260-6. doi: 10.2337/dc12-1204. Epub 2012 Oct 1.

Davidson MB, Duran P, Lee ML, Friedman TC.

Department of Internal Medicine, Division of Endocrinology, Metabolism and Molecular Medicine, Charles R. Drew University, Los Angeles, CA, USA. mayerdavidson@cdrewu.edu

^Comment by VitaminDWiki:

This RCT seems to have done things correctly (Level achieved and 1 year duration), but did not get the anticipated benefit to people with prediabetes

item.title: Low Magnesium and type II diabetes
item.description:
Correlation of magnesium intake with metabolic parameters, depression and physical activity in elderly type 2 diabetes patients: a cross-sectional study.

Huang JH, Lu YF, Cheng FC, Lee JN, Tsai LC.

Graduate Institute of Ph.D. Program in Nutrition and Food Science, Fu-JenCatholic University, New Taipei City, Hsinchuang, Taiwan.

Download the PDF from VitaminDWiki

See also VitaminDWiki

  • Type II Diabetes might be prevented and treated with Magnesium – Review Feb 2015

item.title: Hypothesis: Decreasing Magnesium and increasing CaMg ratio are increasing health problems – 2012 - 2013
item.description:
2 items by A Rosanoff

Suboptimal magnesium status in the United States: are the health consequences underestimated?

Nutr Rev. 2012 Mar;70(3):153-64. doi: 10.1111/j.1753-4887.2011.00465.x. Epub 2012 Feb 15.

Rosanoff A, Weaver CM, Rude RK.

Center for Magnesium Education & Research, 13-1255 Malama Street, Pahoa, HI 96778, USA. ARosanoff@gmail.com

In comparison with calcium, magnesium is an “orphan nutrient” that has been studied considerably less heavily. Low magnesium intakes and blood levels have been associated with type 2 diabetes, metabolic syndrome, elevated C-reactive protein, hypertension, atherosclerotic vascular disease, sudden cardiac death, osteoporosis, migraine headache, asthma, and colon cancer. Almost half (48%) of the US population consumed less than the required amount of magnesium from food in 2005-2006, and the figure was down from 56% in 2001-2002. Surveys conducted over 30 years indicate rising calcium-to-magnesium food-intake ratios among adults and the elderly in the United States, excluding intake from supplements, which favor calcium over magnesium.

item.title: Vitamin D Wiki News for Dec 2012 and
item.description:
Lots of great vitamin D news - here are some news clusters.

More strong evidence and pathway understanding for many diseases

  • Rheumatoid Arthritis strongly associated with low vitamin D – Dec 2012

  • Vitamin D prevents multiple sclerosis through multiple mechanisms – Jan 2013

  • Vitamin D can both prevent and treat Multiple Sclerosis – review Nov 2012 excellent

  • Risk of going from pre-MS to MS reduced 68 percent with 7100 IU vitamin D – RCT Dec 2012

item.title: Candidate list of top vitamin D papers for 2012
item.description:
By William B. Grant, et al. Dec 25, 2012

This list has about 56 papers. I would like to get it down to 10-12 or so.

The papers included should be important to the general population.

They should also cover a range of topics related to vitamin D.

#F00:CLICK HERE for the winners

Short list of papers - followed by abstracts

Some fraction of the papers have web pages on VitaminDWiki

Asthma

  • Bener A, Ehlayel MS, Tulic MK, Hamid Q. Vitamin D deficiency as a strong predictor of asthma in children. . 2012;157(2):168-75.

Autism

  • Kočovská E, Fernell E, Billstedt E, Minnis H, Gillberg C. Vitamin D and autism: clinical review. . 2012 Sep-Oct;33(5):1541-50.

item.title: Fertility problem (PCOS) reduced by vitamin D, etc: many studies
item.description:
• PCOS risk decreased 27% by Omega-3 (Mendelian study) – Sept 2024
      • PCOS treatment needs about 3,000 IU of Vitamin D - meta-analysis Sept 2024
      • Need more PCOS studies with >3,000 IU dosing - meta-analysis Sept 2023
      • PCOS and vitamin D: a clinical appraisal - Sept 2023
      • PCOS is more than just a fertility problem - PCOS reduces longevity by 1 year - 2023
      • PCOS appears to be helped by Vitamn D, probiotics, Omega-3, etc - meta-analysis Sept 2022
      • PCOS Physiopathology and Vitamin D Deficiency - Aug 2022
      • PCOS - menstrual frequency improved by 50,000 IU Vitamin D/week & low calorie diet - RCT May 2018
      • PCOS problems reduced by Vitamin D plus Omega-3 – RCT June 2018
      • PCOS – Live birth strongly a function of vitamin D level – RCT May 2016
      • PCOS decreased by 2.3 X with Vitamin D - meta-analysis Feb 2017
      • PCOS problems greatly reduced by Vitamin D (50,000 IU weekly) – Oct 2015
      • Therapeutic implications of vitamin D and calcium in overweight women with polycystic ovary syndrome. (8500 IU, 2012)
      • Vitamin D seems to have helped PCOS somewhat (2012)
      • Probable connection: antimüllerian hormone levels - April 2014 50,000 IU weekly helped
      • > 30 ng recommended to reduce PCOS (June 2014)
      • PCOS may be due to being overweight - Turkey (which also has low Vit D) Oct 2014
      • Wikipedia highlights on PCOS
      • PCOS decreased by Magnesium, Zinc, Calcium, and 200 IU of VitaminD - March 2018
      • PCOS treatment by Vitamin D is aided by Metformin - meta-analysis Feb 2024
      • See also web

PCOS risk decreased 27% by Omega-3 (Mendelian study) – Sept 2024

Causal relationship between fertility nutrients supplementation and PCOS risk: a Mendelian randomization study

item.title: Overview Schizophrenia and Vitamin D
item.description:
15 reasons to think that schizophrenia is associated with low vitamin D

  1. 97% of patients with schizophrenia are vitamin D deficient

  2. Schizophrenia varies with latitude (UVB) by 10X (controversy)

  3. Schizophrenia is more common in those with dark skin (when away from the equator)

  4. Schizophrenia is associated with low natal vitamin D

  5. Schizophrenia has been increasing around the world when vitamin D has been decreasing (controversy)

  6. Schizophrenia is associated with low birth rate, which is associated with low vitamin D
